key_points: The investigation into Tiger Woods' car crash in California has concluded.
Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva stated the cause of the crash has been determined but cannot be disclosed due to privacy issues requested by Woods' team.
Officials have reached out to Woods and his personnel about waiving privacy to release the investigation information.
The crash occurred on Feb. 23, involving Woods' car hitting a sign, shearing through a tree, and landing in the brush with major damage.
Earlier reports stated Woods had no recollection of driving or how the crash happened, based on a search warrant affidavit for his vehicle's black box.
Woods was unconscious at some point after the crash but conscious when deputies arrived, according to the affidavit.
Deputy Johann Schloegl noted a witness reported Woods was unconscious initially at the crash scene.
Woods underwent emergency surgery for significant injuries to his right lower extremity and returned home in mid-March for recovery.
Sources say Woods is focused on recovery, feeling lucky to be alive, and appreciates the access to great medical care.
Woods confirmed on social media he is back home continuing his recovery and has reunited with his children.
